abstracts.cdata!:
Overall this project is rated as
            unsatisfactory: a strategic opportunity to achieve
            significant institutional and commercial gains was wasted.
            Water production and waste water treatment capacities were
            not balanced by corresponding water distribution and waste
            water collection capacities; the project has not changed
            significantly the provision of water supply service to lower
            income communities nor the ambient water quality of the
            Nairobi river; and the project has failed completely to
            improve the commercial and financial performance of
            Nairobi's water and sewerage department (WSD) and has
            not resolved issues of WSD autonomy and the incentive
            framework. Lessons learned were that 1) the International
            Development Association (IDA) should not finance projects
            unless the borrower is committed to implementing policy and
            institutional reforms that would guarantee their
            sustainability; 2) IDA should insist on the creation of
            water utility companies prior to financing major development
            projects; 3) IDA should encourage borrowers to seek private
            sector participation options; 4) IDA must carefully design
            financial covenants, watch performance indicators agreed
            upon during negotiations, and act decisively soon after
            evidence of violation appears; and 5) water supply and
            sanitation projects must be designed to achieve a balance
            between production and distribution capacities, and waste
            water treatment and collection capacities so that project
            benefits reach the intended beneficiaries.
